title: Problem Overview
content:
**Erdős Problem #920: Chromatic Numbers of K_k-Free Graphs**

Is g_k(n) ≫ n^{1-1/(k-1)} / (log n)^c for k ≥ 4?

**Status: OPEN** (k=3,4 resolved; k≥5 open)

Connects chromatic numbers to Ramsey theory.
mathContext: The function g_k(n) measures maximum chromatic complexity of K_k-free graphs. Bounds on Ramsey numbers R(k,m) directly translate to bounds on g_k(n).

title: K_k-Free Graph
content:
**IsKFree:**

A graph G is K_k-free if it contains no complete subgraph on k vertices.

For k=3, this means triangle-free.

title: Chromatic Number
content:
**chromaticNumber:**

χ(G) = minimum colors to properly color vertices.

Adjacent vertices must have different colors.

title: Maximum Chromatic Number g_k(n)
Graver-Yackel Upper Bound (1968)
content:
**graver_yackel_1968:**

g_k(n) ≪ (n · log log n / log n)^{1-1/(k-1)}

This is the best known upper bound.

Published in J. Combinatorial Theory (1968).

title: Erdős Bound for k=3 (1959)
content:
**erdos_1959_k3:**

g_3(n) ≫ n^{1/2} / log n

Derived from Ramsey bound R(3,m) ≫ (m/log m)².

The k=3 case is well-understood.

title: Mattheus-Verstraete (2023)
content:
**mattheus_verstraete_2023:**

g_4(n) ≫ n^{2/3} / (log n)^{4/3}

A major breakthrough! Resolves the k=4 case with optimal exponent 2/3.

Via their proof that R(4,m) ≫ m³/(log m)⁴.

title: General Lower Bound
content:
**general_lower_bound:**

g_k(n) ≫ n^{1-2/(k+1)} / (log n)^{c_k}

This is WEAKER than conjectured (exponent 1-1/(k-1)).

For k ≥ 5, there's still a gap.

title: The Erdős Conjecture
content:
**ErdosConjecture:**

For k ≥ 4: g_k(n) ≫ n^{1-1/(k-1)} / (log n)^c

Conjectured exponent: 1-1/(k-1)
Known exponent: 1-2/(k+1)

The gap grows with k.

title: The Gap
content:
**the_gap:**

k=4: known=3/5, conjectured=2/3 (RESOLVED by MV2023!)
k=5: known=2/3, conjectured=3/4 (GAP)
k=6: known=5/7≈0.71, conjectured=4/5=0.8 (GAP)

The gap 2/(k+1) - 1/(k-1) grows slowly with k.

title: Ramsey-Chromatic Connection
content:
**ramsey_chromatic_connection:**

If R(k,m) ≥ m^α / (log m)^β
⟹ g_k(n) ≥ n^{1-1/α} / (log n)^{β/α}

Better Ramsey bounds give better chromatic bounds!

title: Mattheus-Verstraete Ramsey Bound
content:
**mattheus_verstraete_ramsey:**

R(4,m) ≫ m³ / (log m)⁴

This was THE breakthrough of 2023!
α=3, β=4 ⟹ g_4(n) exponent = 1-1/3 = 2/3 ✓

title: Erdős Problem #920: OPEN
content:
**erdos_920:**

Status: OPEN for k ≥ 5

The general conjecture remains unresolved.
